Fig. 1 Synthesis process of Rh@H-S-1 catalyst. Fig. 2 XRD pattern of catalysts. Fig. 3 N2 adsorption and desorption isotherms of catalysts. Fig. 4 The SEM images of Silicalite-1 (a) and 1%Rh@H-S-1 catalyst (b, c, d). Fig. 5 The TEM images of 1%Rh/S-1 (a, d, e, f, g), 1%Rh@S-1 (b) and 1%Rh@H-S-1 (c, h, i, j, k). Fig. 6 Yield, distribution and TOF of heptanal over different catalysts (TOS of 2 h) (a) (reaction conditions: 1-hexene = 1 g, P=5 MPa, CO/H2 = 1, solvent toluene = 4.5 mL, mcatalyst = 0.1 g, T=100 °C, t = 2 h); Arrhenius plot for apparent activation energies of catalysts (b), where k is the heptanal generation rate constant. Fig. 7 The XPS spectra of catalysts (a) and in situ XPS spectra (b) of 1%Rh@H-S-1 after the treatment under reaction condition at different temperature. Fig. 8 H2-TPR profiles of different catalysts. Fig. 9 H2-TPD (a) and CO-TPD (b) profiles of different catalysts. Fig. 10 In situ DRIFT spectra of 1 %Rh@H-S-1 and the enlargement of spectra in the range of 2300–2000 cm−1. Fig. 11 1-hexene hydroformylation over catalysts for successive recycles. (reaction conditions: 1-hexene = 1 g, P=5 MPa, CO/H2 = 1, solvent toluene = 4.5 mL, mcatalyst = 0.1 g in the first run, T=100 °C, reaction time = 2 h). Fig. 12 1-hexene hydroformylation over catalysts for successive recycles. Graphical abstract A hollow zeolite encapsulated Rh catalyst Rh@H-S-1 with an “eggshell” structure was prepared using the method of organic alkali treatment and recrystallization. Compared with catalysts with directly encapsulated Rh@S-1 and surface impregnated Rh/S-1, this catalyst exhibited both superior activity and a higher TOF value in hydroformylation of 1-hexene due to the high dispersion of Rh and high diffusion. The Rh element did not need to be reduced in the preparation, and it was in situ reduced by the syngas. The content of lower valence Rhδ+ gradually increased with the reaction procedure and played as an active center. The low oxidized state Rh+ or Rhδ+ in the form of Rh(CO)2 are proposed as active sites in hydroformylation, which were generated under the synergistic effect between CO and H2. Importantly, the hollow encapsulated catalyst effectively decreased Rh leaching to 0.1 ppm and showed better stability compared with the impregnated Rh/S-1 catalyst. Keywords Hollow Encapsulate Hydroformylation Reaction mechanism Rh leaching Stability Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The hydroformylation of olefins is used to produce aldehydes and is one of the most important homogeneous catalytic reactions in industrial production [1]. Its “atom economy” is important aldehyde products, which undergo further oxidation, hydrogenation, and reductive amination to produce high-value chemicals including acids, alcohols and amines, and has attracted more attention [2,3]. The typical catalyst of Rhodium-phosphine complex exhibits superior performance under mild conditions [4]. However, the separation of the catalyst from the product is difficult and is accompanied by high loss of the expensive Rhodium element. In response to this issue, the heterogeneity of homogeneous Rh-based catalysts was widely studied to reduce the Rh loss and improve the stability [5]. A common method is immobilization, which involves fixing active sites by impregnation [6] and grafting on various supports such as carbon materials [7–10], silica [11–14], metal oxides [15,16] and organic polymers [17–20]. Zeolite with ordered channels is widely used in various fields of catalysis and gas adsorption [21,22]. The uniform structure and higher specific surface area make it a typical support, and it is applied in the hydroformylation reaction [23–25]. Zhou et al. [26,27] anchored phosphine ligands on the surface of MCM-41 zeolite, then rhodium was coordinated with the anchored phosphine ligands to immobilize rhodium on the surface, forming complex active sites. The study found that when MCM-41 was used as a support, the conversion of 1-octene was 85.2 %, and the leaching rate of rhodium was 0.15 %. Marras et al. [28] prepared a Rh-xantphos complex catalyst supported on SBA-15 with a uniformly distributed ligand. In the hydroformylation of 1-octene, 94 % of linear aldehyde was obtained, and the catalyst could be easily recovered through simple filtration. However, a trace of Rh metal was detached after the reaction. Zhang et al. [29] immobilized Rh-PPh3 active sites onto three types of mesoporous zeolites; the conversion of 1-octene could reach 99 %, and the selectivity was also above 92 %. The solid composite catalyst could be recycled without loss of activity, but a significant decrease in selectivity due to the leaching of Rh metal was observed. Carrilho et al. [30] immobilized Rh-phosphoramidite complexes on the surface of MCM-41 using both chemical bonding and physical adsorption methods. The researchers compared the differences in the hydroformylation reaction performance of styrene between the two catalysts. Both catalysts achieved high conversion and the selectivity of aldehyde products, but the leaching of Rh for both catalysts was observed, especially for the catalyst by physical adsorption method 79 % of Rh was leached in a single experiment. Therefore, it is necessary to rationally design a catalyst so as to avoid or reduce the leaching of Rh metal. Phosphine ligand modification can improve the activity and ideal product selectivity of Rh-based zeolite catalysts; however, the high cost, instability, and difficulty in separating these ligands hinder the further use of catalysts. Consequently, direct encapsulation of Rh metal within zeolites has been extensively inve et al.stigated. Liu et al. [31] reported the heterogeneous rhodium oxide encapsulated within microporous silicalite-1 (S-1) zeolite (Rh2O3@S-1) through epitaxial growth of S-1 seeds pre-anchored with rhodium species. It was found that the inherent steric hindrance of S-1 zeolite channels inhibited the production of internal olefins and the subsequent formation of isoaldehydes, thus exhibiting enhanced regioselectivity compared with the supported Rh2O3/S-1 catalyst. Zhang et al. [32] selectively encapsulated subnanometer rhodium clusters within the sinusoidal 10-membered ring (10MR) channels of MFI zeolite, aiming at hydroformylation of long-chain linear α-olefins (C6-C12) toward high selectivity of linear aldehyde products. Under optimal conditions, the ratio of linear to branched aldehyde reached up to 400. The high regioselectivity was attributed to the unique coordination environment surrounding the rhodium clusters within the sinusoidal 10MR channels of MFI zeolite. Wang et al. [33] found that the proper encapsulation of Rh species comprising Rh(I)-gem-dicarbonyl centers within a MEL zeolite framework, achieving over 99 % regioselectivity to n-butanal at a turnover frequency (TOF) of product formation rate 6500 h−1. The zeolite framework acts as a scaffold to steer the reaction pathway of the intermediates confined in the space between zeolite framework and Rh centers towards the exclusive formation of n-butanal. In response to the limitations of surface immobilization, effective utilization of active centers and reduction of Rh leaching, hollow zeolite-encapsulated catalyst Rh@H-S-1 was designed and synthesized by organic base treatment followed by recrystallization. Comparative studies were conducted in catalytic performance and Rh leaching of catalysts with impregnated and encapsulated. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Tetraethylorthosilicate (TEOS, 98 %, Sinopharm), tetrapropylammonium hydroxide solution (TPAOH, 25 wt%, Sinopharm), Rhodium Chloride Hydrate (RhCl3·3H2O, Rh: 38.5–42.5 %, Aladdin), Ethylenediamine (EDA, ≥99 %, Sinopharm), 1-hexene (C6H12, 99 %, Macklin), toluene (C7H8, 99.5 %, Sinopharm), Isopropanol (C3H8O, ≥99.7, Sinopharm). 2.2 Preparation of catalysts 2.2.1 Synthesis of Silicalite-1 zeolite In a typical experiment, 15.4 mL of tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) was added dropwise to tetrapropylammonium hydroxide (TPAOH) aqueous solution and the final composition was 1TEOS: 0.17TPAOH: 37H2O. After stirring the mixture at 35 °C for 6 h, it was transferred into a 100 mL of batch reactor lined with Teflon. Crystallization was carried out at 170 °C for 3 days. Then the product was centrifuged and washed to neutrality, followed by overnight dried at 100 °C and calcined at 550 °C for 6 h to obtain Silicalite-1 zeolite. 2.2.2 Preparation of 1 %Rh/S-1 The RhCl3·3H2O was dissolved in water and then added to Silicalite-1 zeolite powder with small drops under ultrasonic environment, accompanied by stirring. The amount of Rh metal was 1 % of the mass of the support. Next, the thoroughly stirred mixture was dried overnight at 80 °C and calcined at 550 °C for 6 h to obtain the catalyst, designated as 1 %Rh/S-1. 2.2.3 Preparation of 1 %Rh@H-S-1 The 0.3 M TPAOH solution was mixed with the 1 % Rh/S-1 synthesized above (solid–liquid ratio of 1:10 (g:mL)). The mixture was put into a crystallization kettle with a PTFE lining, and was crystallized at 170 °C for 72 h. The mixture after reaction was centrifuged and dried, and then calcined at 550 °C for 6 h to obtain the catalyst named 1 %Rh@H-S-1. The overall synthesis process was shown in Fig. 1 . 2.2.4 Preparation of 1 %Rh@S-1 The catalyst 1 %Rh@S-1 was prepared according to reference [34]. The excess amount of EDA (1 mL) was added to an RhCl3 solution (5 mL, 0.08 mol/L). After thorough mixing, the resulting mixture was incorporated into the synthesis gel of Silicalite-1 zeolite under vigorous stirring, in which the equivalent content of SiO2 to TEOS was about 4.14 g. And the subsequent steps were consistent with the synthesis of silicalite-1 zeolite. The obtained catalyst was named as 1 %Rh@S-1. 2.3 Characterization methods The crystal phase of the sample was examined utilizing a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffraction (XRD) instrument, equipped with a Cu Kα radiation source (λ = 0.154 nm). The operational parameters comprised 40 kV and 40 mA, and the scanning speed was set at 5°/min. The pore texture of the samples was characterized on a JW-BK132F N2 physical adsorption device. The samples were pretreated in a He atmosphere at 350 °C and degassed for 10 h. After the pretreatment, the samples were tested at 77.15 K and N2 partial pressure of 10-8-10-1, then the N2 adsorption and desorption curve, pore size distribution and specific surface area of the samples were obtained. The metal content in solid/liquid samples was determined employing an Agilent 5110 inductively coupled plasma emission spectrometer (ICP-OES). The morphology and elemental distribution of the samples were tested using a ZEISS Sigma 300 scanning electron microscope (SEM) and a JEOL JEM-F200 transmission electron microscope (TEM) equipped with Energy Dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements and pseudo in situ XPS characterizations were carried out using an AXIS SUPRA+X-ray photoelectron spectrometer. The XPS PEAK4.1 software was employed for peak fitting on XPS spectra. The catalysts were treated with a syngas atmosphere (CO:H2 = 1:1, 5 MPa) at different temperatures for 1h in the high-pressure reactor, and after which, it was transferred to the analysis chamber for XPS measurement without exposure to air. The H2 temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was performed using a BELCAT II instrument equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). A 50 mg sample was placed in a quartz tube and pretreated with high-purity Ar at 150 °C for 1 h to remove moisture and other contaminants. The sample was then cooled to room temperature, and a gas flow of 10 %H2-Ar at a rate of 30 cm3·min−1 was introduced. The temperature was ramped at a rate of 10 °C·min−1 up to 750 °C while recording the sample temperature and TCD signal. The CO temperature programmed desorption (CO-TPD) was conducted using the same BELCAT II instrument. After the same pretreatment procedure, the sample was cooled to 50 °C, and 10 %CO-He gas pulses were repeated until adsorption saturation. Subsequently, a flow of He at 30 cm3·min−1 was introduced for 30 min to remove residual gases and physically desorbed CO from the sample surface. The sample was then heated at a rate of 10 °C·min−1 in He up to 750 °C while recording the TCD signal. The H2-temperature programmed desorption (H2-TPD) was also conducted using the same BELCAT II instrument and the same procedure as CO-TPD except the 10 %H2-Ar gas was used. The in situ Diffuse Reflectance Infrared Fourier Transformations Spectroscopy (DRIFTS) was recorded on a Bruker TENSOR II spectrometer equipped with a cell (Hattrick). The catalyst sample was pretreated at 300 °C in an Ar flow (30 mL·min−1) for 1 h, then cooled down to the reaction temperature (100 °C). The background spectrum was recorded first. Next, CO/H2 (1:1, 20 mL·min−1) was switched into the in situ cell system passing through a 20 mL of reactant (1-hexene/toluene) for reaction, subsequently the spectra were recorded for 60 min. 2.4 Evaluation of catalytic performance The catalyst evaluation experiment was conducted in a high-pressure reactor equipped with mechanical agitation. In a standard reaction, 1.0 g of 1-hexene, 0.1 g of catalyst, and 4.5 mL of toluene were introduced into a 50 mL Teflon-lined reactor. The reactor was sealed and purged with syngas (CO:H2 = 1:1) three times. The reaction was carried out under the set conditions. The products were analyzed based on the internal standard method on a gas chromatogram (Agilent GC 8890, FID, HP-5 capillary column (60 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 μm)) using isopropanol as a quantitative internal standard. The conversion of 1-hexene (X), selectivity of each product (S), ratio of heptanal in products (n/i) and turnover frequency (TOF) [35–37] were calculated using the following formulas: X = n 1 - h e x e n e i n r e a c t a n t - n 1 - h e x e n e i n p r o d u c t n 1 - h e x e n e i n r e a c t a n t × 100 % S = n product n Total p r o d u c t × 100 % n i = n n - h e p t a n a l n i - h e p t a n a l × 100 % TOF( h - 1 )= Yielded heptana l (mmol) Rh content (mmol) × Reaction time (h) ( r e a c t i o n t i m e = 5 m i n ) . 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of catalysts 3.1.1 Crystal phase The hollow zeolite-encapsulated Rh catalyst was synthesized through a method involving recrystallization after organic base treatment. The MFI crystal impregnated with Rh underwent recrystallization using a TPAOH solution. Numerous Si-OH groups on the single crystal surface of the zeolite lost protons in an alkaline medium, resulting in a highly negatively charged surface. The TPA ions preferentially adhered to the zeolite crystal surface through electrostatic interactions with Si-O- to reduce the dissolution of the outer surface of the zeolite. At the same time, silicate oligomers were dissolved from the inside of the crystal, and the leached silicate oligomers interacted with TPA aggregates on the zeolite surface to form a silicate/TPA intermediate state[38], which was then recrystallized at 443 K. Continuous desiliconization and recrystallization promoted the synthesis of hollow silicalite-1 nanocubes, and the activity of surface immersion was solidified in the zeolite. The large internal cavity was used to eliminate the restriction of internal diffusion on the reactivity. The pores of zeolite were used as channels connecting the inner and outer space. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) was used to characterize the crystal phases of Silicalite-1 series catalysts, as shown in Fig. 2 . The Silicalite-1 series catalysts exhibit typical crystal phases of MFI zeolite[39,40], and obvious characteristic diffractions were observed at 2θ = 7.8°, 8.7°, 23.1°, 23.9° and 24.4°, which are corresponding to the (101), (200), (051), (151) and (133) crystal faces of the MFI zeolite topology. This is consistent with the standard diffraction card (PDF#44-0696) for MFI zeolite (Silicalite-1). Recrystallization did not affect the crystal phase structure of Silicalite-1 zeolite, and no detectable lattice distortion was induced. Notably, no characteristic diffraction peaks attributed to rhodium particles were identified, suggesting that rhodium is highly dispersed or below the detection limit. Interestingly, due to the large radius of the Rh atom, the lattice constant gradually increases with the embedding and encapsulation of the Rh atom (Table S1). 3.1.2 Textural property The N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms were depicted in Fig. 3 , and are classified as type IV isotherm with H4 type hysteresis loop [41]. The BET specific surface areas range from 360 to 444 m2/g (Table 1 ), which could provide sufficient reaction interface. The hysteresis loops of silicalite-1, Rh/S-1 and encapsulated Rh@S-1 samples all appeared around P/P0 = 0.9, while that of hollow Rh@H-S-1 showed a large hysteresis loop in P/P0 = 0.4 ∼ 0.9, suggesting a mesoporous-microporous composite structure. The organic base treatment and subsequent recrystallization resulted in the formation of hollow structures within the 1 %Rh@H-S-1 catalyst. This process leads to a broad distribution of mesopores in 1 %Rh@H-S-1, whose volume reached 0.144 cm3/g comprising nearly half of the total pore volume (Table 1). This extensive mesoporous network will be advantageous for the diffusion of large molecules during the reaction process[42,43]. For 1 %Rh/S-1 and 1 %Rh@S-1 catalysts, the micropore is the majority. Their micropore volumes reached about 0.16 cm3/g while the mesopore volumes were only about 0.06 cm3/g. 3.1.3 Morphology The morphology of different samples was observed through SEM and TEM as shown in Fig. 4 and Fig. 5 . The single crystals of Silicalite-1 are almost uniformly organized with dimensions of approximately 300 nm, and the crystals exhibit a typical hexagonal prism morphology. The shape of hollow encapsulated samples synthesized via recrystallization methods exhibited no apparent alteration, yet the single crystal size increased to about 500 nm, which effectively validated the occurrence of surface recrystallization processes[44]. By comparing the TEM images of different samples in Fig. 5, it was observed that the Rh metal in the impregnated catalyst primarily aggregated on the single crystal surfaces. The aggregation of active metals on the zeolite surface reduced atomic utilization efficiency and was easy to desorption and separation during the reaction process. In contrast, for the encapsulated catalyst, Rh metal was immobilized within the zeolite crystal and exhibited a uniform dispersion. Furthermore, the hollow encapsulated catalyst featured significantly larger and regular cavities within its crystals. 3.2 Hydroformylation of 1-hexene The Rh content in different catalysts was determined by ICP-OES (Table S2). In order to investigate the performance disparities among impregnated, directly encapsulated, and hollow encapsulated samples, the difference in 1-hexene hydroformylation to aldehyde was compared. Firstly, the optimal reaction conditions were studied by controlling the variable method with 1-hexene as the reaction substrate (Fig. S1) and showed: Rh loading capacity 1 %, reaction pressure 5 MPa, reaction time 2 h and reaction temperature 100 °C. Under the best conditions, the differences in reaction activity among 1 %Rh/S-1, 1 %Rh@S-1 and 1 %Rh@H-S-1 catalysts were compared as depicted in Fig. 6 and Table S3. Comparative analysis revealed that under optimal conditions, the yields of heptanal after reaction for 1 %Rh/S-1, 1 %Rh@S-1, and 1 %Rh@H-S-1 catalysts were 81.61 %, 95.20 %, and 95.98 %, respectively (with residual products including small amounts of iso-hexene, hexane, and heptanol). The n/i ratio of heptanal were 0.71, 0.79, and 0.74, respectively, and the turnover frequencies (TOF) for heptanal production were 3471 h−1, 1725 h−1, and 3461 h−1, respectively. The traditional surface-impregnated catalyst exhibits relatively lower activity, yet higher turnover frequency (TOF) within short durations. This phenomenon suggests that the contribution of Rh metal exposed on the external surface to the formation of heptanal is greater than that of the internally encapsulated portion over brief periods. The catalytic activity of directly encapsulated catalyst is similar to that of hollow encapsulated catalyst. However, the turnover frequency (TOF) of directly encapsulated catalysts is relatively lower, reaching only about half of that of corresponding surface-impregnated catalysts and hollow encapsulated catalysts. This is speculated to be due to the microporous structure of MFI zeolite restricting reaction diffusion, thus affecting mass transfer efficiency and preventing the attainment of ideal TOF values within short durations. Conversely, hollow encapsulated catalysts effectively mitigate the impact of internal diffusion on reaction efficiency, achieving performance comparable to that of impregnated catalysts and realizing relatively ideal TOF values. The hollow zeolite-encapsulated catalyst 1 %Rh@H-S-1 achieves a heptanal yield of over 95 % and demonstrates ideal turnover frequency (TOF) values, highlighting the structural and catalytic advantages of hollow encapsulated catalyst. It is noteworthy that when the active component is encapsulated within the zeolite, the n/i ratio of heptanal under identical conditions is relatively high, reflecting the shape-selective effect of the MFI zeolite structure[39,45]. Additionally, a kinetic study on the hydroformylation of 1-hexene to produce heptanal was conducted. The evolution of heptanal yield and reaction time at different temperatures on catalysts was performed (Table S4-S6). Based on the reaction rate constants (k) at different temperatures[46], the Arrhenius plot for the hydroformylation of 1-hexene in the temperature range of 80–100 °C was obtained, and the apparent activation energy (E a) for heptanal formation was calculated. Three catalysts had similar values of k and E a as seen in Fig. 6b, Fig. S2-S4. The slight difference in Ea might be accounted for the difference in the diffusion or accessibility of reactant due to the different location of active centers. 3.3 Plausible reaction mechanism The chemical valence state of Rh in various catalysts was detected and compared, alongside the discrepancies in chemical adsorption at different temperatures, to explore the reasons for the difference in hydroformylation over different catalysts. Furthermore, the chemical state transitions of Rh in hollow zeolite encapsulated catalyst 1 %Rh@H-S-1, and the corresponding functional group formations during the reaction were further investigated through in situ XPS and in situ DRIFT. The Rh in the impregnated sample 1 %Rh/S-1 exists in an oxidized state of Rh3+ with the binding energy of 312.9 eV and 308.1 eV (Fig. 7 a) [47]. The new valence of Rh with a content of 29.98 % in the directly encapsulated catalyst 1 %Rh@S-1 was observed and showed Rhδ+ (0 < δ < 1) with a binding energy of 312 eV and 307.3 eV (Table 2 ), which is attributed to the Rh anchored inside the zeolite and bonded with Si-O to form Si-O-Rh [41]. The in situ formed Rhδ+ represents the averaged chemical valence of Rh0 and Rh1+ [35]. The presence of Rhδ+ was also detected in hollow zeolite encapsulated catalyst 1 %Rh@H-S-1, with its content relatively increased to 37.02 %. In order to further investigate the role of Rh in 1 %Rh@H-S-1 catalyst during the reaction, pseudo-in situ XPS analysis was performed under reaction conditions, and the results are shown in Fig. 7b. It was found that with the increase of reaction temperature, the chemical valence state of Rh in the catalyst gradually decreased, while the content of Rhδ+ gradually increased (Table 2). At a reaction temperature of 100 °C, Rhδ+ became the predominant valence state, accounting for about 60 % of the Rh in the catalyst, which was mainly due to the further in situ reduction by syngas [47,48]. Fig 8 illustrates the H2-TPR profiles of different catalysts, showing notable disparities between impregnated and encapsulated catalysts. Impregnated catalyst exhibits only one main reduction peak around 156 °C, corresponding to the reduction of surface-adsorbed Rh on the 1 %Rh/S-1 catalyst. In contrast, encapsulated catalysts manifest two distinct reduction peaks, corresponding to the high-temperature reduction of surface-adsorbed Rh and encapsulated Rh respectively. The higher reduction temperature for encapsulated Rh might be attributed to the strong interaction between Rh and the support and the formation of anchored Rh with a surface Si-O bond. The relatively lower reduction temperature around 140 °C observed in encapsulated catalysts is attributed to the Rh freely dispersed on the surface like that in impregnated one. The H2-TPD and CO-TPD were employed to determine the differences in chemisorption and the results are shown in Fig. 9 . The chemical adsorption results of 1 %Rh/S-1 and directly encapsulated catalyst 1 %Rh@S-1 exhibit similarity, while the TPD profile of hollow encapsulated catalyst 1 %Rh@H-S-1 manifests richer desorption peaks. This is attributed to the greater mesoporous distribution within the catalyst, which facilitates more extensive reaction diffusion [49], thereby promoting the occurrence of CO chemical adsorption and generating a more abundant active species. The H2-TPD profile also shows corresponding desorption peaks in this temperature range, indicating a synergistic effect between H2 and CO on the generation of specific components in hollow encapsulated catalyst 1 %Rh@H-S-1 during the reaction process. Moreover, the peaks at relatively high temperatures suggest that the more stable active species exist. In order to understand the types and the formation of Rh active species in catalyst as well as the process of hydroformylation, under the reaction atmosphere (1-hexene and CO/H2 = 1:1) the in situ DRIFT spectra for 1 %Rh@H-S-1 were collected and the results are shown in Fig. 10 . The wavenumber ranges of 3000–2800 cm−1 and 1400–1100 cm−1 are associated with the symmetric and asymmetric stretching vibration of C–H (CH3) respectively, and the 3100–3050 cm−1 is assigned to =C–H stretching vibration, these all belong to the characteristic functional groups of 1-hexene [50]. The wavenumber range of 2300–2000 cm−1 is mainly the characteristic functional groups of Rh-CO complexes. The initial appearance of peaks at wavenumbers of 2174 and 2117 cm−1 are indicative of the oxidized Rh3+ species interacting with free CO molecules[51,52]. With the progress of the reaction, CO undergoes chemical adsorption combined with the reduction of H2, resulting in a decrease of peak intensity at the 2174 and 2117 cm−1 wavenumbers. New characteristic peaks emerge in the lower wavenumber region at 2143, 2104, and 2088 cm−1. Among these, the peaks around 2104 and 2088 cm−1 are attributed to the symmetric and asymmetric stretches of atomically dispersed Rh gem-dicarbonyl species (Rh(CO)2) [15,53,54], while the minor peak at 2143 cm−1 is assigned to Rh(CO)(O), formed due to incomplete reduction of Rh [55]. The low oxidized state Rh+ or Rhδ+ in the form of Rh(CO)2 are proposed as active sites in hydroformylation [25,47,56]. Furthermore, according to the TPD profiles, the active species generated by the synergistic action of H2 and CO exhibits relatively high thermal stability. With the increase in reaction time, the signal corresponding to the –CHO functional group at 1717 cm−1 increases [14], demonstrating the formation of heptanal. 3.4 Stability It was found that the reaction activity of the hollow encapsulated catalyst was relatively superior to that of the traditional impregnated catalyst. In order to explore the advantages of the hollow encapsulated catalyst in reducing Rh leaching, the activity differences between 1 %Rh/S-1 and 1 %Rh@H-S-1 were studied in five consecutive cycles under the same conditions (Fig. 11 ), and the Rh content in the reaction mixture was determined by ICP-OES (Table S7, S8, S9). It was found that the yield of heptanal in the fifth cycle over 1 %Rh/S-1 catalyst was only 40.51 %, while that over 1 %Rh@H-S-1 was still above 90 % under the same conditions. After five cycles, the total Rh leaching of 1 %Rh@S-1 and 1 %Rh@H-S-1 catalysts were 19.58 % and 22.43 %, while that for 1 %Rh/S-1 catalyst reached 61.06 %. The leaching of Rh metal after reaction over encapsulated catalyst was significantly lower than that over impregnated catalyst. In the initial experiments, the Rh leaching rates for three catalysts were all relatively huge, which was primarily attributed to metal particles attached to the catalyst surface or those with weaker binding ability to the support [57]. These prove the better stability of encapsulated Rh-based catalyst. So, it is concluded that the obvious changes in heptanal yield over 1 %Rh/S-1 are mainly due to some changes caused by higher Rh leaching during the reaction process, such as those in the structure of active centers or reaction kinetics or others which need to be discovered. In order to further compare the Rh leaching between both kinds of catalysts, a study with a further reaction time of 24 h was conducted after five recycles (Fig. 11). The results showed that all yields of heptanal were recovered to above 90 % after further 24-hour reaction and the activity for three catalysts seemed similar. However, the Rh leaching for encapsulated 1 %Rh@H-S-1 after further 24-hour reaction was only 0.13 ppm which is equivalent to 0.052 ‰ of the Rh mass per hour, while that for 1 %Rh/S-1 reached 1.02 ppm which was equivalent to 0.88 ‰ of the Rh mass per hour, further proving the better stability of encapsulated catalyst than impregnated catalyst. The valence of Rh on the surface of 1 %Rh@H-S-1 after recycle tests was characterized by XPS and no noticeable signals were found as seen in Fig. 7(a), indicating that there were no Rh atoms on the external surface, which meant the Rh atoms in the encapsulated Rh@H-S-1 were mainly distributed inside of zeolite S-1[58,59]. Interestingly, even though the external Rh on 1 %Rh@H-S-1 was leached after 24-hour reaction under high-temperature and high-pressure, it still showed excellent activity that the yield of heptanal all remained above 92 % in the next three reaction recycles (Fig. S5). In addition, the stability in catalytic performance at low conversion for three catalysts were compared and the results are shown in Fig. 12 . The encapsulated catalysts of Rh@S-1 and Rh@H-S-1 all maintained excellent cyclic stability compared to their initial activities, while the impregnated catalyst Rh/S-1 exhibited a significant decrease during the several cycles. The difference in catalytic activation between Rh@S-1 and Rh@H-S-1, with a close amount of Rh active centers, are owing to the difference in diffusion or the accessibility of reactants due to different structures. And the obvious deactivation of Rh/S-1 is attributed to the loss of active Rh centers during cycles. This further demonstrates the higher stability of encapsulated catalyst than impregnated one. Especially for Rh@H-S-1, it not only showed a higher TOF value, but also showed higher stability. 4 Conclusions Hollow zeolite-encapsulated Rh-based catalyst (Rh@H-S-1) was designed and prepared by impregnation and TPAOH treatment, which not only encapsulated Rh atoms inside the zeolite, but also created more mesopores and a big cavity in a single cell of Silicalite-1 for diffusion. For reactions with big reactants, the diffusion is important. The hollow structure made the active centers more distributed close to the surface to form an “eggshell” catalyst. The TPAOH treatment provided recrystallization to distribute Rh atoms well and encapsulate them well. For synthesized Rh@S-1 (without TPAOH treatment), all Rh atoms would be distributed inside single cells of S-1; therefore, even supported the same content of Rh atoms with Rh@H-S-1, the latter had a higher TOF value due to the better diffusion. For an impregnated catalyst, the active Rh atoms mainly aggregated on the surface of S-1, and the effective active centers were decreased. So, even supported the same content of Rh atoms, encapsulated Rh@H-S-1 had a higher yield of heptanal (95.98 %) than impregnated Rh/S-1 (81.61 %). In addition, encapsulation provided better stability. More interesting and worthy is that encapsulated Rh@H-S-1 had better resistance to Rh leaching without an obvious decrease in its activity. Even after removing the external Rh atoms, it kept high activity while losing only 0.13 ppm of Rh atoms after a 24-hour reaction. The in situ experiments demonstrated that the valence state of Rh atoms would be fast reduced by CO/H2 to form real active centers, which means there is no need to reduce Rh atoms when preparing. In conclusion, the heterogeneous catalyst of hollow encapsulated Rh@H-S-1 for olefin hydroformylation is advantageous in preparation, diffusion, activity, stability and resistance to Rh leaching, which provides an effective approach for designing and preparing new heterogeneous catalysts for olefin hydroformylation. coredata.dc:description: A hollow zeolite encapsulated Rh catalyst Rh@H-S-1 with an “eggshell” structure was prepared using the method of organic alkali treatment and recrystallization. Compared with catalysts with directly encapsulated Rh@S-1 and surface impregnated Rh/S-1, this catalyst exhibited both superior activity and a higher TOF value in hydroformylation of 1-hexene due to the high dispersion of Rh and high diffusion. The Rh element did not need to be reduced in the preparation, and it was in situ reduced by the syngas. The content of lower valence Rhδ+ gradually increased with the reaction procedure and played as an active center. The low oxidized state Rh+ or Rhδ+ in the form of Rh(CO)2 are proposed as active sites in hydroformylation, which were generated under the synergistic effect between CO and H2. Importantly, the hollow encapsulated catalyst effectively decreased Rh leaching to 0.1 ppm and showed better stability compared with the impregnated Rh/S-1 catalyst.
